title: Definition: Category
text:
A category is a mathematical structure consisting of objects and morphisms (arrows) between them, with a composition operation satisfying certain axioms.


A category \(\mathcal{C}\) consists of:

A collection of objects, denoted \(\text{Ob}(\mathcal{C})\)
For each pair of objects \(A, B\), a Set of morphisms (or arrows) from \(A\) to \(B\), denoted \(\text{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B)\)
For each triple of objects \(A, B, C\), a composition operation: \[\circ: \text{Hom}(B, C) \times \text{Hom}(A, B) \to \text{Hom}(A, C)\]

satisfying:



Identity: For each object \(A\), there exists an identity morphism \(\text{id}_A \in \text{Hom}(A, A)\) such that:

\(f \circ \text{id}_A = f\) for all \(f: A \to B\)
\(\text{id}_A \circ g = g\) for all \(g: B \to A\)

Associativity: For morphisms \(f: A \to B\), \(g: B \to C\), \(h: C \to D\): \[h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f\]






Set: Objects are sets, morphisms are functions
Grp: Objects are groups, morphisms are group homomorphisms
Top: Objects are topological spaces, morphisms are continuous functions
Vect: Objects are vector spaces, morphisms are linear transformations

title: Definition: Morphism
text:
A morphism (also called an arrow) is a fundamental concept in Category theory representing a structure-preserving map between objects.


In a Category \(\mathcal{C}\), a morphism \(f: A \to B\) consists of: - A domain (or source) object \(A\) - A codomain (or target) object \(B\) - An abstract “arrow” \(f\) from \(A\) to \(B\)



For morphisms in a category, we have:

Composition: If \(f: A \to B\) and \(g: B \to C\), then there exists a composite morphism \(g \circ f: A \to C\)
Identity: For each object \(A\), there exists an identity morphism \(\text{id}_A: A \to A\)
Associativity: \((h \circ g) \circ f = h \circ (g \circ f)\) whenever the compositions are defined
Identity laws: \(f \circ \text{id}_A = f\) and \(\text{id}_B \circ f = f\) for \(f: A \to B\)




The collection of all morphisms from \(A\) to \(B\) in category \(\mathcal{C}\) is denoted: - \(\text{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B)\) or - \(\mathcal{C}(A, B)\) or - \(\text{Mor}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B)\)



Special types of morphisms include: - Monomorphism: A categorical generalization of injective functions - Epimorphism: A categorical generalization of surjective functions - Isomorphism: A morphism with a two-sided inverse

title: Example: The Category of Sets
text:
The category Set is one of the most fundamental examples in Category theory, with sets as objects and functions as morphisms.


The category Set consists of: - Objects: All Set s - Morphisms: Functions between sets - Composition: Function composition - Identity: The identity function on each set



We verify that Set satisfies the axioms of a category:


For functions \(f: A \to B\), \(g: B \to C\), and \(h: C \to D\): \[(h \circ g) \circ f = h \circ (g \circ f)\]
This holds because function composition is associative: for any \(x \in A\), \[((h \circ g) \circ f)(x) = h(g(f(x))) = (h \circ (g \circ f))(x)\]



For each set \(A\), the identity function \(\text{id}_A: A \to A\) defined by \(\text{id}_A(x) = x\) satisfies: - For any \(f: A \to B\): \(f \circ \text{id}_A = f\) - For any \(g: B \to A\): \(\text{id}_A \circ g = g\)





Size: Set is a large category - its collection of objects forms a proper class, not a set
Special Morphisms:

Monomorphisms in Set are exactly the injective functions
Epimorphisms in Set are exactly the surjective functions
Isomorphisms in Set are exactly the bijective functions

Initial and Terminal Objects:

The empty set \(\emptyset\) is the initial object (unique function from \(\emptyset\) to any set)
Any singleton set \(\{*\}\) is a terminal object (unique function from any set to \(\{*\}\))






FinSet: The category of finite sets
Set* The category of pointed sets (sets with a distinguished element)

title: Definition: Binomial Coefficient
text:
The binomial coefficient \(\binom{n}{k}\) (read “n choose k”) counts the number of ways to choose \(k\) objects from \(n\) objects without regard to order.


For non-negative integers \(n\) and \(k\) with \(k \leq n\), the binomial coefficient is defined as:
\[\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}\]
where \(n!\) denotes the factorial of \(n\).




In terms of Combination: \(\binom{n}{k} = C(n,k)\) - the number of k-combinations from n elements
In terms of Permutation: \(\binom{n}{k} = \frac{P(n,k)}{k!}\) where \(P(n,k)\) is the number of k-permutations
Recursive definition: \[\binom{n}{k} = \binom{n-1}{k-1} + \binom{n-1}{k}\] with base cases \(\binom{n}{0} = \binom{n}{n} = 1\)





\(\binom{n}{0} = 1\) (one way to choose nothing)
\(\binom{n}{1} = n\) (n ways to choose one item)
\(\binom{n}{n} = 1\) (one way to choose everything)
\(\binom{n}{k} = 0\) if \(k > n\) (cannot choose more items than available)





Symmetry: \(\binom{n}{k} = \binom{n}{n-k}\)
Pascal’s Identity: \(\binom{n}{k} = \binom{n-1}{k-1} + \binom{n-1}{k}\)
Binomial Theorem: \((x + y)^n = \sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} x^k y^{n-k}\)





Counting subsets of a given size
Expansion of binomial expressions
Probability calculations in discrete distributions
Pascal’s triangle construction

title: Definition: Permutation
text:
A permutation of a Set is a bijective function from the set to itself.


Let \(S\) be a set. A permutation of \(S\) is a bijection \(\sigma: S \to S\).
For a finite set \(S = \{1, 2, ..., n\}\), a permutation can be represented as a rearrangement of the elements.



Permutations can be written in several ways:

Two-line notation: \[\sigma = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 & ... & n \\ \sigma(1) & \sigma(2) & \sigma(3) & ... & \sigma(n) \end{pmatrix}\]
One-line notation: \(\sigma = [\sigma(1), \sigma(2), ..., \sigma(n)]\)
Cycle notation: \((a_1\ a_2\ ...\ a_k)\) means \(a_1 \mapsto a_2 \mapsto ... \mapsto a_k \mapsto a_1\)





The set of all permutations of \(n\) elements forms the symmetric group \(S_n\)
The number of permutations of \(n\) distinct elements is \(n!\)
Every permutation can be decomposed into disjoint cycles
Every permutation can be expressed as a product of transpositions




For \(S = \{1, 2, 3\}\): - Identity: \((1)(2)(3)\) - Transposition: \((1\ 2)(3)\) - 3-cycle: \((1\ 2\ 3)\)

title: Definition: Euclidean Space
text:
An \(n\)-dimensional Euclidean space, denoted \(\mathbb{E}^n\), is the vector space \(\mathbb{R}^n\) equipped with the standard inner product and the induced metric.


The \(n\)-dimensional Euclidean space consists of:

The underlying set: \(\mathbb{R}^n = \{(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n) : x_i \in \mathbb{R}\}\)
The standard inner product: For \(\mathbf{x} = (x_1, \ldots, x_n)\) and \(\mathbf{y} = (y_1, \ldots, y_n)\), \[\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \rangle = \sum_{i=1}^n x_i y_i\]
The Euclidean norm: \[\|\mathbf{x}\| = \sqrt{\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x} \rangle} = \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2}\]
The Euclidean metric: \[d(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) = \|\mathbf{x} - \mathbf{y}\| = \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - y_i)^2}\]





Complete metric space: Every Cauchy sequence converges
Finite-dimensional: Has dimension \(n\) as a vector space
Locally compact: Every point has a compact neighborhood
Simply connected: For \(n \geq 2\)
Homogeneous: Looks the same at every point





\(\mathbb{E}^1\): The real line
\(\mathbb{E}^2\): The Euclidean plane
\(\mathbb{E}^3\): Three-dimensional Euclidean space

title: Example: Euclidean Metric on ℝⁿ
text:
The n-dimensional Euclidean space \(\mathbb{R}^n\) with the Euclidean distance forms a Metric Space.


For points \(x = (x_1, x_2, ..., x_n)\) and \(y = (y_1, y_2, ..., y_n)\) in \(\mathbb{R}^n\), the Euclidean distance is:
\[d(x, y) = \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i - y_i)^2}\]



We verify that \(d\) satisfies all properties of a metric:

Non-negativity: \(d(x, y) \geq 0\) since it’s a square root of a sum of squares.
Identity of indiscernibles:

If \(x = y\), then \(x_i = y_i\) for all \(i\), so \(d(x, y) = 0\).
If \(d(x, y) = 0\), then \(\sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i - y_i)^2 = 0\), which implies \(x_i = y_i\) for all \(i\), so \(x = y\).

Symmetry: \(d(x, y) = d(y, x)\) since \((x_i - y_i)^2 = (y_i - x_i)^2\).
Triangle inequality: For any \(x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^n\): \[d(x, z) \leq d(x, y) + d(y, z)\] This follows from the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality.





\(n = 1\): The usual absolute value metric on \(\mathbb{R}\): \(d(x, y) = |x - y|\)
\(n = 2\): The familiar distance in the plane: \(d((x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2)) = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}\)
\(n = 3\): The distance in 3D space used in physics and engineering

title: Theorem: Pythagorean Theorem
text:
In a Euclidean space, two vectors are orthogonal if and only if the square of the norm of their sum equals the sum of the squares of their norms.


Let \(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \in \mathbb{E}^n\). Then:
\[\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \rangle = 0 \quad \text{if and only if} \quad \|\mathbf{x} + \mathbf{y}\|^2 = \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 + \|\mathbf{y}\|^2\]



(\(\Rightarrow\)) Suppose \(\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \rangle = 0\). Then: \[\begin{align}
\|\mathbf{x} + \mathbf{y}\|^2 &= \langle \mathbf{x} + \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{x} + \mathbf{y} \rangle \\
&= \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x} \rangle + 2\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \rangle + \langle \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{y} \rangle \\
&= \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 + 2 \cdot 0 + \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 \\
&= \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 + \|\mathbf{y}\|^2
\end{align}\]
(\(\Leftarrow\)) Suppose \(\|\mathbf{x} + \mathbf{y}\|^2 = \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 + \|\mathbf{y}\|^2\). Expanding the left side: \[\begin{align}
\|\mathbf{x} + \mathbf{y}\|^2 &= \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 + 2\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \rangle + \|\mathbf{y}\|^2
\end{align}\]
Comparing with the given equality: \[\|\mathbf{x}\|^2 + 2\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \rangle + \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 = \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 + \|\mathbf{y}\|^2\]
Therefore, \(2\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \rangle = 0\), which implies \(\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \rangle = 0\).



In \(\mathbb{E}^2\), for a right triangle with legs of length \(a\) and \(b\) and hypotenuse of length \(c\): \[a^2 + b^2 = c^2\]

title: Definition: Power Set
text:
The power set of a set \(A\), denoted \(\mathcal{P}(A)\) or \(2^A\), is the set of all subsets of \(A\).


\[\mathcal{P}(A) = \{B : B \subseteq A\}\]
In other words, \(B \in \mathcal{P}(A)\) if and only if every element of \(B\) is also an element of \(A\).




Always contains the empty set: \(\emptyset \in \mathcal{P}(A)\) for any set \(A\)
Always contains the original set: \(A \in \mathcal{P}(A)\)
Cardinality: If \(|A| = n\) (finite), then \(|\mathcal{P}(A)| = 2^n\)
Ordering: \(\mathcal{P}(A)\) forms a partially ordered set under inclusion





If \(A = \emptyset\), then \(\mathcal{P}(A) = \{\emptyset\}\)
If \(A = \{1\}\), then \(\mathcal{P}(A) = \{\emptyset, \{1\}\}\)
If \(A = \{1, 2\}\), then \(\mathcal{P}(A) = \{\emptyset, \{1\}, \{2\}, \{1, 2\}\}\)
If \(A = \{a, b, c\}\), then: \[\mathcal{P}(A) = \{\emptyset, \{a\}, \{b\}, \{c\}, \{a,b\}, \{a,c\}, \{b,c\}, \{a,b,c\}\}\]





\(A \subseteq B\) if and only if \(\mathcal{P}(A) \subseteq \mathcal{P}(B)\)
\(\mathcal{P}(A \cap B) = \mathcal{P}(A) \cap \mathcal{P}(B)\)
\(\mathcal{P}(A) \cup \mathcal{P}(B) \subseteq \mathcal{P}(A \cup B)\) (but not always equal)

title: Definition: Greatest Common Divisor
text:
The greatest common divisor (GCD) of two integers is the largest positive integer that divides both numbers.


Let \(a, b \in \mathbb{Z}\), not both zero. The greatest common divisor of \(a\) and \(b\), denoted \(\gcd(a, b)\), is the unique positive integer \(d\) such that:

\(d \mid a\) and \(d \mid b\) (i.e., \(d\) divides both \(a\) and \(b\))
If \(c \mid a\) and \(c \mid b\) for some integer \(c\), then \(c \mid d\)




\(\gcd(a, b)\) is the largest element in the set: \[\{d \in \mathbb{Z}^+ : d \mid a \text{ and } d \mid b\}\]




Commutativity: \(\gcd(a, b) = \gcd(b, a)\)
Associativity: \(\gcd(a, \gcd(b, c)) = \gcd(\gcd(a, b), c)\)
Identity: \(\gcd(a, 0) = |a|\) for \(a \neq 0\)
Scaling: \(\gcd(ka, kb) = |k| \cdot \gcd(a, b)\) for any integer \(k\)
Bézout’s Identity: There exist integers \(x, y\) such that \(\gcd(a, b) = ax + by\)




The GCD can be computed efficiently using the Euclidean algorithm: \[\gcd(a, b) = \gcd(b, a \bmod b)\]
Repeating until the remainder is 0.




\(\gcd(a, a) = |a|\)
\(\gcd(a, 1) = 1\) for any integer \(a\)
If \(\gcd(a, b) = 1\), we say \(a\) and \(b\) are coprime or relatively prime





\(\gcd(12, 18) = 6\)
\(\gcd(17, 19) = 1\) (17 and 19 are coprime)
\(\gcd(0, 5) = 5\)
\(\gcd(−24, 36) = 12\)




For a finite set of integers \(\{a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n\}\) not all zero: \[\gcd(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n) = \gcd(a_1, \gcd(a_2, \ldots, a_n))\]



graph TD

    B --> D[c | a, c | b ⟹ c | d]
    A --> E[Properties]
    E --> F[Commutative]

title: Definition: Greatest Common Divisor
text:
Let \(a, b \in \mathbb{Z}\), not both zero. The greatest common divisor of \(a\) and \(b\), denoted \(\gcd(a, b)\), is the unique positive integer \(d\) such that:

\(d \mid a\) and \(d \mid b\) (i.e., \(d\) divides both \(a\) and \(b\))
If \(c \mid a\) and \(c \mid b\) for some integer \(c\), then \(c \mid d\)

title: Definition: Greatest Common Divisor
text: \(\gcd(a, b)\) is the largest element in the set: \[\{d \in \mathbb{Z}^+ : d \mid a \text{ and } d \mid b\}\]

title: Definition: Greatest Common Divisor
text:
Commutativity: \(\gcd(a, b) = \gcd(b, a)\)
Associativity: \(\gcd(a, \gcd(b, c)) = \gcd(\gcd(a, b), c)\)
Identity: \(\gcd(a, 0) = |a|\) for \(a \neq 0\)
Scaling: \(\gcd(ka, kb) = |k| \cdot \gcd(a, b)\) for any integer \(k\)
Bézout’s Identity: There exist integers \(x, y\) such that \(\gcd(a, b) = ax + by\)

title: Definition: Greatest Common Divisor
text:
The GCD can be computed efficiently using the Euclidean algorithm: \[\gcd(a, b) = \gcd(b, a \bmod b)\]
Repeating until the remainder is 0.

title: Definition: Greatest Common Divisor
text:
\(\gcd(a, a) = |a|\)
\(\gcd(a, 1) = 1\) for any integer \(a\)
If \(\gcd(a, b) = 1\), we say \(a\) and \(b\) are coprime or relatively prime

title: Definition: Greatest Common Divisor
text: For a finite set of integers \(\{a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n\}\) not all zero: \[\gcd(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n) = \gcd(a_1, \gcd(a_2, \ldots, a_n))\]

title: Theorem: Euler’s Theorem
text:
For any integer \(a\) coprime to \(n\), we have \(a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\), where \(\phi(n)\) is Euler’s totient function.


Let \(n \geq 1\) be an integer and let \(a\) be an integer with \(\gcd(a, n) = 1\). Then: \[a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\]
where \(\phi(n)\) counts the number of integers \(k\) with \(1 \leq k \leq n\) and \(\gcd(k, n) = 1\).



For a positive integer \(n\): - If \(n = p\) is Prime Number, then \(\phi(p) = p - 1\) - If \(n = p^k\), then \(\phi(p^k) = p^k - p^{k-1} = p^{k-1}(p - 1)\) - If \(\gcd(m, n) = 1\), then \(\phi(mn) = \phi(m)\phi(n)\) (multiplicative)



The integers coprime to \(n\) form a Group under multiplication modulo \(n\), denoted \((\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^*\). This group has order \(\phi(n)\), so by Lagrange’s theorem, any element raised to the group order equals the identity.




Fermat’s Little Theorem: When \(n = p\) is prime, \(\phi(p) = p - 1\), giving \(a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\)
Carmichael’s Theorem: A refinement using the Carmichael function \(\lambda(n)\)





RSA cryptography
Primality testing
Computing modular inverses: \(a^{\phi(n)-1} \equiv a^{-1} \pmod{n}\)

title: Definition: Expected Value
text:
The expected value (or expectation) of a random variable is a measure of the central tendency of its distribution, representing the average value the random variable takes over many trials.


For a discrete random variable \(X\) with probability mass function \(p(x)\):
\[E[X] = \sum_{x} x \cdot p(x)\]
where the sum is taken over all possible values of \(X\).



For a continuous random variable \(X\) with probability density function \(f(x)\):
\[E[X] = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x \cdot f(x) \, dx\]



For a random variable \(X\) on a probability space \((\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P)\):
\[E[X] = \int_{\Omega} X(\omega) \, dP(\omega)\]
This is the Lebesgue integral of \(X\) with respect to the probability measure \(P\).




Linearity: \(E[aX + bY] = aE[X] + bE[Y]\) for constants \(a, b\)
Monotonicity: If \(X \leq Y\) (almost surely), then \(E[X] \leq E[Y]\)
Constant: \(E[c] = c\) for any constant \(c\)
Non-negativity: If \(X \geq 0\) (almost surely), then \(E[X] \geq 0\)




The expected value exists if and only if \(E[|X|] < \infty\), i.e., when: \[\int_{\Omega} |X(\omega)| \, dP(\omega) < \infty\]




Bernoulli: If \(X \sim \text{Bernoulli}(p)\), then \(E[X] = p\)
Binomial: If \(X \sim \text{Binomial}(n, p)\), then \(E[X] = np\)
Normal: If \(X \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2)\), then \(E[X] = \mu\)
Exponential: If \(X \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)\), then \(E[X] = 1/\lambda\)

title: Definition: Random Variable
text:
A random variable is a measurable function from a Probability Space to a measurable space.


Given a probability space \((\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P)\), a random variable is a function \(X: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}\) such that for every Borel set \(B \subseteq \mathbb{R}\):
\[X^{-1}(B) = \{\omega \in \Omega : X(\omega) \in B\} \in \mathcal{F}\]
This condition ensures that we can assign probabilities to events of the form \(\{X \in B\}\).




Discrete Random Variable: Takes countably many values

Characterized by probability mass function (PMF): \(p_X(x) = P(X = x)\)

Continuous Random Variable: Takes uncountably many values

Characterized by probability density function (PDF): \(f_X(x)\) where \(P(a \leq X \leq b) = \int_a^b f_X(x) dx\)






Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF): \(F_X(x) = P(X \leq x)\)
Expected Value: \(E[X] = \int_{\Omega} X(\omega) dP(\omega)\)
Variance: \(\text{Var}(X) = E[(X - E[X])^2]\)





Bernoulli: \(X \in \{0, 1\}\) with \(P(X = 1) = p\)
Normal: \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\)
Poisson: \(P(X = k) = \frac{\lambda^k e^{-\lambda}}{k!}\)

title: Theorem: Law of Large Numbers
text:
The Law of Large Numbers states that the sample average of independent and identically distributed random variables converges to their expected value as the sample size increases.


Let \(X_1, X_2, \ldots\) be independent and identically distributed random variables with finite expected value \(\mu = E[X_i]\) and finite variance \(\sigma^2 = \text{Var}(X_i)\).
Define the sample average: \[\bar{X}_n = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i\]
Then for any \(\epsilon > 0\): \[\lim_{n \to \infty} P(|\bar{X}_n - \mu| > \epsilon) = 0\]
This is convergence in probability: \(\bar{X}_n \xrightarrow{P} \mu\).



Under the same conditions, we have almost sure convergence: \[P\left(\lim_{n \to \infty} \bar{X}_n = \mu\right) = 1\]
This is written as: \(\bar{X}_n \xrightarrow{a.s.} \mu\).



Using Chebyshev’s inequality: \[P(|\bar{X}_n - \mu| > \epsilon) \leq \frac{\text{Var}(\bar{X}_n)}{\epsilon^2}\]
Since the \(X_i\) are independent: \[\text{Var}(\bar{X}_n) = \text{Var}\left(\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i\right) = \frac{1}{n^2} \sum_{i=1}^n \text{Var}(X_i) = \frac{\sigma^2}{n}\]
Therefore: \[P(|\bar{X}_n - \mu| > \epsilon) \leq \frac{\sigma^2}{n\epsilon^2} \to 0 \text{ as } n \to \infty\]




Empirical frequencies converge to probabilities
Sample means approximate population means
Foundation for statistical inference
Monte Carlo methods




For fair coin flips (Bernoulli(1/2)), the proportion of heads converges to 1/2 as the number of flips increases.

    F --> H[P(|X̄ₙ - μ| > ε) → 0]
    G --> I[P(lim X̄ₙ = μ) = 1]

title: Definition: Compact Space
text:
A Topological Space is compact if every open cover has a finite subcover.


A topological space \((X, \tau)\) is compact if for every collection \(\{U_i\}_{i \in I}\) of Open Set such that \(X = \bigcup_{i \in I} U_i\), there exists a finite subset \(J \subseteq I\) such that \(X = \bigcup_{j \in J} U_j\).



For a topological space \(X\), the following are equivalent:

\(X\) is compact
Every collection of closed sets with the finite intersection property has non-empty intersection
Every net in \(X\) has a convergent subnet
Every filter on \(X\) has a cluster point





Closed subsets of compact spaces are compact
Compact subsets of Hausdorff spaces are closed
The continuous image of a compact space is compact
The product of compact spaces is compact (Tychonoff’s theorem)





Any finite topological space is compact
The closed interval \([a, b]\) in \(\mathbb{R}\) is compact (Heine-Borel theorem)
The unit sphere \(S^n\) in \(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\) is compact

title: Definition: Open Set
text:
Let \((X, \tau)\) be a Topological Space. A subset \(U \subseteq X\) is called an open set if and only if \(U \in \tau\).


By the definition of a topology, open sets have the following properties:

The empty set \(\emptyset\) and the entire space \(X\) are open
Any union of open sets is open
Any finite intersection of open sets is open







Open intervals \((a, b) = \{x \in \mathbb{R} : a < x < b\}\) are open sets
Closed intervals \([a, b]\) are not open sets
Half-open intervals \([a, b)\) and \((a, b]\) are not open sets
The entire real line \(\mathbb{R}\) is open
Any union of open intervals is open





Every subset is an open set





Only \(\emptyset\) and \(X\) are open sets





Open sets can be thought of as sets where every point has some “wiggle room” around it that stays within the set. This intuition is formalized in metric spaces, where a set is open if every point has an open ball around it contained in the set.




Definition: Closed Set (complement of an open set)
Theorem: Union of Open Sets (proves a fundamental property)
Definition: Interior of a Set (coming soon)
Definition: Neighborhood (coming soon)

title: Example: Closed Interval is Compact
text:
The closed interval \([a, b]\) in \(\mathbb{R}\) (with the standard topology) is a Compact Space space.


For any \(a, b \in \mathbb{R}\) with \(a \leq b\), the closed interval \([a, b] = \{x \in \mathbb{R} : a \leq x \leq b\}\) is compact.



Compactness of \([a, b]\) means that from any collection of open sets that cover \([a, b]\), we can always select a finite number of them that still cover \([a, b]\). This captures the idea that \([a, b]\) is “finite in extent” despite containing infinitely many points.



By the Heine-Borel Theorem, a subset of \(\mathbb{R}^n\) is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded. We verify:

Closed: \([a, b]\) is closed because its complement \((-\infty, a) \cup (b, \infty)\) is open.
Bounded: \([a, b]\) is bounded since all its elements lie between \(a\) and \(b\).

Therefore, \([a, b]\) is compact.




The open interval \((a, b)\) is not compact (it’s bounded but not closed)
The ray \([a, \infty)\) is not compact (it’s closed but not bounded)
The entire real line \(\mathbb{R}\) is not compact (it’s closed but not bounded)




The compactness of closed intervals is fundamental in analysis: - It ensures that continuous functions on \([a, b]\) attain their maximum and minimum - It’s key to proving the uniform continuity of continuous functions on \([a, b]\) - It’s essential for the Riemann integrability of continuous functions

title: Theorem: Heine-Borel Theorem
text:
A subset of Euclidean space \(\mathbb{R}^n\) is Compact Space if and only if it is Closed Set and bounded.


For a subset \(K \subseteq \mathbb{R}^n\) (with the standard Metric Space topology), the following are equivalent:

\(K\) is compact
\(K\) is closed and bounded

where bounded means there exists \(M > 0\) such that \(\|x\| \leq M\) for all \(x \in K\).





If \(K\) is compact in \(\mathbb{R}^n\), then: - \(K\) is closed (since \(\mathbb{R}^n\) is Hausdorff) - \(K\) is bounded (by considering the open cover \(\{B(0, n)\}_{n=1}^{\infty}\))



If \(K\) is closed and bounded in \(\mathbb{R}^n\), then \(K\) is compact.





Characterizing compact sets in finite-dimensional normed spaces
Proving existence of extrema for continuous functions
Establishing convergence of sequences in \(\mathbb{R}^n\)

title: Theorem: Union of Open Sets
text:
Let \((X, \tau)\) be a Topological Space. Then the union of any collection of open sets is open.


If \(\{U_i\}_{i \in I}\) is any collection of open sets (where \(I\) is an arbitrary index set), then \[\bigcup_{i \in I} U_i \in \tau\]



This follows directly from the definition of a topology.
Let \(\{U_i\}_{i \in I}\) be an arbitrary collection of sets where each \(U_i \in \tau\).
By the second axiom in the definition of a Topological Space, the arbitrary union of sets in \(\tau\) must also be in \(\tau\).
Therefore, \(\bigcup_{i \in I} U_i \in \tau\), which means \(\bigcup_{i \in I} U_i\) is open. \(\square\)



This theorem holds for arbitrary unions, including: - Finite unions - Countably infinite unions
- Uncountably infinite unions
However, the analogous statement for intersections is not true in general. Only finite intersections of open sets are guaranteed to be open.




In \(\mathbb{R}\) with the standard topology:

\(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} (-\frac{1}{n}, \frac{1}{n}) = (-1, 1)\) is open
\(\bigcup_{x \in (0,1)} (x - \frac{1}{2}, x + \frac{1}{2}) = (-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{2})\) is open

Counter-example for infinite intersections:

\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} (-\frac{1}{n}, \frac{1}{n}) = \{0\}\) is not open in \(\mathbb{R}\)





This property is fundamental in: - Defining basis and subbasis for topologies - Constructing new topological spaces - Proving continuity of functions
